name: Ásbyrgi Canyon - Iceland's Horseshoe-Shaped Wonder
description: Ásbyrgi represents one of Iceland's most spectacular geological formations, created as 3.5-kilometer-long horseshoe-shaped glacial canyon carved by catastrophic floods from Jökulsá á Fjöllum river during two separate events—first eruption occurring 8,000-10,000 years ago and second approximately 3,000 years ago when massive glacial outburst floods (jökulhlaups) from Vatnajökull glacier carried enormous volumes of water, ice, and debris downstream carving canyon's distinctive U-shape into bedrock with vertical cliffs rising up to 100 meters creating protected amphitheater. The canyon forms northern anchor of Jökulsárgljúfur section within Vatnajökull National Park, positioning Ásbyrgi as gateway attraction for visitors exploring Diamond Circle route and northern Iceland's geological wonders where combination of accessibility, dramatic scenery, and hiking opportunities make it one of region's most visited natural sites. The horseshoe shape measures approximately 1 kilometer wide at opening and narrows toward closed end where Eyjan (The Island) rock formation rises as cliff-top promontory dividing canyon into eastern and western sections, creating vantage point offering panoramic views across canyon floor, surrounding cliffs, and distant mountains visible on clear days. The canyon floor hosts Botnstjörn pond fed by groundwater creating tranquil water feature and wildlife habitat rare in Iceland's often barren landscapes.
address: Ásbyrgi, Vatnajökull National Park, Northeast Iceland
